Input.threadtitle: Why is the speed of a falling object increasing?
Input.posts:
The gravity force are constant. But why the object what is falling down is increasing in speed?
Upvotes:
-1
Hi johann. In Newton´s first law: An object that is at rest will stay at rest unless an external force acts upon it. An object that is in motion will not change its velocity unless an external force acts upon it. In that case gravity force is acting over the object during all way long (not only at the start), this is the reason of the aceleration. I hope this answer help you.
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Since falling occurs so quickly, it's hard to see the increasing speed of a falling object. You know instinctively that the speed continues to increase because you are more concerned about being hit by a falling apple that has dropped 10 meters than one that has dropped 1 meter. However, I suggest you watch Galileo's experiment: let a ball roll down a slightly tipped ramp. The physics is very similar to falling, but it occurs much more slowly. Watch how the ball's speed increases steadily as it descends. The ball is experiencing a constant downhill force and is accelerating downhill at a constant rate. As a result, its speed increases steadily. After all, acceleration is the rate at which velocity is changing with time. Lou

Input.threadtitle: Skating Part 1 - Why doesn't a slow knife cut the apple?
Input.posts:
When doing the table cloth/apple cut 'tricks', why does the cloth/knife have to be executed quickly?\xA0 Why would slowly removing the table cloth or cutting with the knife effect the object's inertial tendency to remain still more than doing it quickly?
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Even though it is very sharp, the knife pushes a little bit on the apple. With enough time, that push will cause the apple to start moving fast enough to spoil the cutting process. By moving the knife as fast as I can, I limit the time over which the knife pushes on the apple and allow the apple's inertia to dominate the situation. The knife then succeeds in cutting the apple. The same is true for the tablecloth and dishes. There is a small frictional force on the dishes as the tablecloth moves underneath them. If I go to slow, that frictional force will get the dishes moving and they'll leave the table. By going fast, I minimize this nuisance effect and leave the dishes behind. Lou

Input.threadtitle: Falling Balls-Part 4:  How to calculate the Velocity?
Input.posts:
Where am I going wrong? \xA0The bowling ball falling out the window shows the position and time to the right of the window.... At 1.0 sec, the ball is 5 meters from the window from which it was dropped. \xA0So, the average velocity starting from the initial drop is 5m/s. \xA0(i.e. the ball traveled 5 meters in 1 sec, so 5 divided by 1 is 5m/s) Then, how did he calculate the instantaneous velocity of 10m/s? \xA0I would assume then he just used calculus? \xA0Or took a very short increment of time \xA0and position that he didn't show to calculate the 10m/s?
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
During its first second of falling, the bowling ball goes from moving at velocity = 0 to velocity = 10 m/s downward. Input.threadtitle: What does sliding friction do to the momentum of a moving box?
Input.posts:
Episode 5 part 3 looks at what happens to a moving box coming to a full stop on an 'unmoving' table due to sliding friction. Revisiting this situation\xA0 after watching the bumper car lectures:\xA0 does friction violate the conservation of the linear momentum of the box-table(earth) system? \xA0Can the table truly remain unmoving? (If not, why is the box not doing positive work on the table, while it is doing negative work on the box?) I\xA0 am guessing that the momentum is conserved, but completely masked by all the other physics Professors who crash their wagons at the same time onto their tables at different angels (and other interactions)..... or in other words that to observe the conservation of motion is only possible when looking at an isolated system. But at a microscopic level: if friction transforms the kinetic energy of the box into unusable heat energy, is the overall directional component of the momentum still conserved in the erratic heat movements? Thanks for some answers....
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Good question. Momentum is conserved, so the idea of an 'unmoving' table is an oversimplification. The sliding box transfers its momentum to the table & Earth (the table and Earth are essentially attached to one another). As a result of this momentum transfer, the box slows to a stop and the table & Earth experience a tiny change in velocity in the direction of the box's original momentum. But because the table & Earth have such an enormous mass, it's impossible to measure that tiny change in the table & Earth's velocity. Moreover, we (the camera) are attached to the Earth, too, so we experience the same tiny change in momentum. I should be careful about making overly strong statements such as 'unmoving table', at least without explaining that I am oversimplifying. Lou
